7RrmWuQsox0kOyoGbx4ICQ.text: On our last visit to London's Soho district my husband & I  went to get something to eat at Koya's Restaurant.  What  we discovered was that Koya Restaurant  was gone and a new Restaurant, Hoppers was in its place.  The Koya Bar is still open for business  & is right next door to Hoppers Restaurant.  When we got to Hoppers there was a long line to get in.  We decided try the next day for lunch & we were able to get in.  Hoopers is a very small restaurant.  The food was very spicy and good.  My husband and I shared the Goat Roti, Chicken Kari & a plan hopper. E6kArcZJZqz3Kki8fPVbzQ.text: I have to say this was one of my best meals in London to date.  So good I was finally sparked off my bum to write a review after many years in the dark.They don't take reservations so get here early - luckily they do a virtual line - so they call you when your table is available, so just head elsewhere to enjoy some drinks while you wait.There were five of us - tightly packed into a small table, but there was enough room for us to move and eat comfortably.For drinks I had both the Quart of Milk Panch (shared), which surprisingly wasn't overly coy or milky - I'm assuming because it is cardamom "milk" and not milk from an animal and the Wonder Tonic, which was pretty juicy and sweet.  But not in the best way.  This is the only area I felt that the menu fell a little flat for me.  The drinks were small - which is fine for the price point as long as they are strong - which they weren't.  Next time I'm sticking to wine or beer.Now for food:"Short Eats"- Lotus Root, Cashew & Ash Plaintain Fry - these were literally crisps made out of these various tubular plants and they were delicious, and came with a dipping sauce that carried a real kick. Would order again.- Goat Roti, Rasa - I enjoyed this (because I thoroughly enjoyed their roti), but it was simile and not overly flavourful when compared to the other dishes. But it got mixed reception from our group. I would order again, don't know if anyone else would.- Idli, Sambhar, Podi - I only had a bite, and I wasn't that taken back.  It was tasty, but almost like a very fluffy pancake in sauce.  I wasn't going back for seconds.  However, one of the others of our group (vegetarian) love it, so an option for people only eating veg.- Calamari Fry, Chemmeen Podi - the calamari was small, so maintained its crispy crunchiness. The sauce accompaniment provided a nice flavour.  Would order gain. "Sides"- Roti - I'm used to north indian roti, which is quite "whole mealy" This roti was completely different.  Almost like puff pastry roti.  Light and delicious. Would order again. (In fact we ordered seconds)"Hoppers + Dosas"- Egg Hopper - here is another item we ordered two rounds off.  This is like a thin crispy pancake in the shape of a bowl with a fried egg at the bottom.  The first was fully cooked the second was runny - and they were both delicious.  The pancake part is great for eating with kari, the egg tasted amazing on its own or with a selection of chutney's we got.- Dosa - Thin crispy, everything you want in a dosa.  I find these great accompaniments to karis again as they aren't as heavy as rice or naans, which means you can have more bites!"Karis"- Red Pumpkin Kari - good vegetarian choice.  While this was yummy and I would suggest again, it wasn't my favourite kari.  Less flavourful than other options, but would probably order again.- Fish Kari - this was made with salmon in a red sauce, and it was amazing.  Fish, not fishy, flaky delicious. The Kari sauce was flavourful with a kick (most of the food has at least a little kick), enough that we were sopping up every last bite. Even my friend who doesn't like salmon loved it.- Chicken Kari - this was ordered as round two as we liked the other two karis so much.  it wasn't nearly as good as either the pumpkin or fish kari.  Served in a spicy green sauce. Chicken was cooked well - moist and tender, just not my style."Rice, Roast & Kothu"I saved the best for last- Lam kothu roti - We ordered the lamb kothu roti as it came recommended and we wanted to order something lamb.  This is chock full of veg and kothu roti - which is roti chopped up and stir fried in with the veg and meat.  This was AMAZING. Flavourful, spicy, perfect balance of oil to keep it moist without feeling oily. I mean this was amazing.  We ate it all in less than 5 minutes.  So good we had to order round two...- Vegetable kothu - AMAZING. Felt healthy but still very flavourful. I think this has no eggs so also veg friendly.  Spicy and tasty. I'm struggling to explain the flavours in these dishes because I literally have never tasted anything  like this before.Everyone at the table left full, but not in pain, and happy and wanting to go back for more!I will definitely be back to this place, cannot recommend highly enough. :)

ryBhBKEa1V3g2A5Q4Fk8ng.text: Sri Lankan food is harder to come by in California, so I really wanted to try this place. It seems like it would be kind of hip, but the food was still authentic.  Many of the words on the Sri Lankan menu are more foreign to me, so it's nice that they have a glossary.  We did everything family style.Drinks:- Wonder tonic: tropical, a bit too sweet for me; rum based- Sambol garita: basically like a margarita with some extra kick - Arrack attack: the favorite drink for both of us - the ginger beer adds just the right amount of heatFood:- Brinjal moju: "pickled" eggplant; it actually wasn't sour. The eggplant had tons of flavor, and it was sweet and garlicky. The texture was interesting, too. It's definitely worth a try (it's a small cup)- Egg hopper: a coconut batter basket (sort of like a dosa shaped into a basket) with a runny egg in the center. I prefer the outer edge's texture since it's thinner and crisper.  The egg's seasoning was very good, but the rest of it was better with chutney and curry- Dosa: wonderful flavor, nice and thin; it left us wanting to order another one - Chutneys: ordered on the side - orange, green, and white (tomato based, herb based, nut based)- Red pumpkin kari: a red curry that's awesome for dipping the dosa and hopper - Ceylonese spit chicken: a small roast chicken with amazing flavor. The herb crust and the skin are super flavorful, and even the white meat had flavor in itself. It was a great roast chicken, which could definitely rival the Zuni one in SF.  It come with pol roti (thick pancake), but I preferred the dosa.  It also had a sambol that was like a red curry, which was great for dipping thingsI was very happy with this meal. The food was interesting, and all the flavors were really well balanced. Prices are also reasonable.It's a pretty small space with no reservations, so plan ahead.  We came around 10pm on a Friday night (close to closing), and the wait was under 10 min.  I would definitely come back.

But it's not a big deal because they text you when your table is ready so we wandered off for pre-dinner drinks which were easy to find. It took a bit of time to navigate the menu and I had to assist the non south asians at the table. We all ended up with Karis and Hoppers or dosas and chutneys on the side. We were all suffering a bit the next day but we agreed it was worth it. Not sure if we'll be back soon (our stomachs need rest) but I would recommend the place!

zNde8NUOTaC4IaMY4bn8dA.text: I love the growth of London, the demand for more 'authentic' cuisines, beyond the dishes altered for the Western palate like sweet and sour but more for new exciting and exotic flavours.This is how Hoppers became to be so successful, introducing Sri Lankan food you won't be able to find in your local curry house.The restaurant itself has been transformed to bring out the Sri Lankan theme with its reds and dim lighting, patterned wall tiles and carpet. It's a very casual place, shared bench seating and busy atmosphere. With its new, on the door booking system you now don't have to worry about queuing up. Just show up, leave your details at the door and come back when they notify you that your table is ready.Being very excited and eager we ordered the following:Bone marrow varuval, rotiDelicious thick fatty goodness of bone marrow in a mild thick masala curry. The sauce was generous and creamy with complex savoury flavours. It went down so well we tried to mopped it up using the accompanied roti which itself was amazingly light, buttery and doughy.Chicken heart chukka. Similar to calamari it had a lovely bounce to its texture, cooked with a more dry curry paste. It definitely had a lot more punch to it that leaves your tongue numbing in its spice. But truly delicious. Duck roti. Not as great as everyone shouts it out to be being quite dense and dry for my liking. The roti was baked till crisp and duck dry fried with complex flavours. It was quite spicy and exaggerated more so when dipped into the nutty spicier curry that it came with. String hopperKind of forgettable if you ask me as it was literally just a plate of rice noodles. Unless you had a lot of sauce left in your dish to use to mop it up with, it took a lot of flavours away. We may have ordered more sides than karis itself so maybe that was the problem. It was served with spiced desiccated coconut and a milky spicy coconut based dip that were delicious within itself but wasn't enough to make enough impact on the noodles.Podi dosaUnlike the plain dosa, this one comes with a dry spicy powder mix surrounding the inside. It's made of fermented lentils and rice. Kind of wish I ordered a plain one as my mouth was on fire at this point. But still I enjoyed tearing it apart , crackling as I did and somewhat flexible enough for me to turn it into a scoop to eat the karis with it.Egg hopper The infamous hopper itself made of fermented rice batter and coconut milk, somewhat like a thin crispy pancake made into a bowl shape. It had a hint of sourness to it but with a runny fried egg placed on top of it, the rich yolk overtook the flavour. It was a great perfect way to scoop some karis into it and let it soak it before eating it.Guinea fowl kariThe Guinea fowl was practically falling of the bone as soon as we dug in. You can imagine how tender the meat must have been. The curry itself was creamy, mildly spiced with a nice sweetness to it to counteract the heat. Black pork Kari A drier curry of chunky pieces of pork belly cooked in a sticky spicy sauce. The heat was more intense in this dish but it didn't stop me from eating it all up and enjoying the intensity of the juicy tender pork pieces in the lovely spicy flavours.Lamb KothuThe dish I would come back over and over again for. Marinated tender pieces of lamb, thrown in with spices, a lovely ray of vegetables, eggs and small pieces of roti soaking up all the lovely flavours. The combination of textures and flavours were amazing especially with the addition of the egg binding bits and pieces of everything together.Watallapan A spiced coconut custard based pudding, firm at first and then from squidgy to a thick paste as it melts in your mouth. You can taste the notes of cardamom and cloves against the sweetness and of course the nuttiness from the topping of crushed nuts. I wasn't too sure if the texture was satisfying enough for me. It wasn't exactly creamy or smooth but somewhere in between. Still I'm very glad I got to try something new. Durian ice cream They ran out of the milk hopper with treacle, jaggery but was kind enough to just charge us for the durian ice cream it usually comes with. Now Ren who usually runs away at the sight of durian enjoyed this as the coldness of it managed to hide the so called 'horrible smell' (which I personally think smells delicious). dtFiyQn_B_OWQkzLONe6Aw.text: I got off work early one day and took advantage of the opportunity to try and queue for an early dinner at one of London's hottest no reservation restaurants. I was deciding between Bao and Hoppers, and my friend opted for the latter so we showed up at 5:15 PM, 15 minutes before opening, and there was already a 10 person queue. The restaurant is a cozy little place, seating probably only about 30 people, and as we were a group of 2, we were seated at a sharing table in the middle of the restaurant. I thought it was actually a great way to keep table turning and make the most of the small space. If you arrive after all the seats have been filled... tough luck, although they seem to have a system where they can take your phone number and let you know when the table is ready.The good thing is that the menu is relatively simple and you receive your food very quickly (pretty sure almost everything is pre prepared). We were guided by a cheery and efficient waitress who suggested that we get a few of the "short eats," two karis (curries), and a hopper and a dosa. She did, however, fail to warn us that the bone marrow and hot butter devilled shrimp we ordered were dangerously spicy, to the extent that it definitely hampered my enjoyment of the food. The curries went much better, and we liked that the black pork kari and the fish kari are very different in character (there are no descriptions on the menu). The hopper was more spongy, whereas the dosa was crisp and flaky, so we thought the hopper went better with the sauce in the fish kari, whereas the dosa was better for the spiced but not sauce based black pork kari. Both were delicious.As for drinks, they are well known for their cocktails and my friend got the Kung Fu Pandan in a short old fashioned glass, before moving onto one of their lagers, which don't come cheap at £4.50.  They only have wine in a glass or half bottle size, so I got one of the red wines, which only did a moderate job of washing away the extreme spiciness I encountered. W8Yg4GuQ6aUf3lU02-9t2A.text: Recently I went to the new bloggers & critics acclaimed restaurant: Hoppers. Hoppers is a Sri Lankan restaurant owned by Karam, Jyotin and Sunna Sethi, the team behind Trishna and Gymkhana, and based on Frith street. When I heard it was related to Gymkhana, I must say that turned me off a little bit as I had an awful experience there due to bad service.I've tried to go to Hoppers before Christmas but I did not really want to wait and have lunch at 4pm. This was before they introduced their app queuing system. I went to Hoppers last weekend and heard a lot of good things about their app queuing system, unfortunately (or kind of) I didn't get the chance to experiment  with it as I managed to get a table straight away. My sister and I were not familiar at all with Sri Lankan cuisine and dishes. As soon as we were seated, a very nice waiter explained to us the concept and the menu. He recommended that we order a dosa or a hopper which is a bowl-shaped thin pancake made with fermented rice and coconut milk batter, with a karis (equivalent of a curry).We asked for the mildest curry, and were recommend the red pumpkin kari and the lamb kari.We started our meal with two starters which are called 'short eats', we had the mutton rolls and the duck roti. The mutton rolls were nicely crispy on the outside and had mild spiced rich mutton inside, and were served alongside a spicy tomato relish. The duck roti was a minced and spiced duck meat roti pastry and it was served with a nutty spicy sauce. Both starters were delicious, however we had a preference for the mutton rolls but we ate them with the duck roti sauce. My sister and I like spicy food but only when it is not too hot. We made the mistake of drinking all our water with our starters and our mouths started to burn soon after!A nice waiter seeing our distress, asked us if we wanted some yoghurt to calm the heat. We accepted without hesitation and ordered a second bowl to compliment our mains too. It was really nice to have such attentive waiters. For mains, we had one hopper each with a soft-yolked egg baked into it, with all the sauces: Poi Samboi, Seeni Samboi and a coriander chutney. We shared the lamb kari and the red pumpkin kari. The lamb kari was very tender and melt in the mouth, but it was indeed spicy. The pumpkin was probably the most mildest dish of our meal. It went very well with the lamb. We didn't have any dessert as we were too full, but during my next visit I might try one.Overall, despite our mouths being on fire for the whole lunch, we had a very good experience at Hoppers. The team was really nice and attentive, the food was superb, spicy and full of flavours. I will definitely come back to Hoppers if I don't have to queue for hours.In my opinion, the only improvement this restaurant could do in the future will be to offer each dish with different level of spices so everyone can have more options.

1c7OgpfpsnQsBVrQqKM4gg.text: One of the best restaurants in London Soho that you must try especially if you are up for trendy food and never try Sri Lankan cuisine before! We were really impressed with Hoppers and will definitely be back soon to try everything else on the menu.

SRzfIBLaZMfpN0Q5CzH-6g.text: Ooh can the Sethi siblings do no wrong?! They're already behind the likes of Trishna, Gymkhana, Bubbledogs and Bao in London - and now Hoppers, an ode to the eponymous Sri Lankan dish.They don't pull any punches on the flavours here and the whole experience was essentially a rave up for my tastebuds. The sambal, dosa and karis took me straight back to Sri Lanka (as did all the traditional decor touches), with a host of other new flavours too. There's plenty of veg choice but I'm afraid the best flavours are to be found among the meat dishes; the bone marrow varuval with delightfully flaky roti is not to be missed. I was also pleasantly surprised by the chicken heart dish, whilst the whole Ceylonese spit chicken arrives with a flourish and is covered in a spicy, finger-lickingly moreish coating.It's the kind of meal you need you get stuck in with your fingers, and it's an adventurous menu with plenty of unfamiliar dishes - both important reasons to choose your dining companions carefully! I think a group of 4 is optimal - enough to order a load of dishes to share (and you'll want to try plenty) but not enough to wait an age to get seated. If you can get there for 5.30pm opening so much the better but otherwise there'll be queues (though they use qudini so you can easily pop for a drink nearby). We were such keen beans we were actually first in! Thanks to Karan and his team for taking such good care of us - the staff are all up to speed on the more esoteric ingredients. Your adventurous eating will be rewarded by good value for money too - I was surprised when the amount of food we ate came to less than £20 a head. is9IG3_0h6UeYCmSK3T08A.text: Obsessed with the meal I had here 2 nights ago.  I've never had Sri Lankan food before and was blown away by everything I ate.  Specifically the curry bone marrow appetizer was the best thing I've eaten in a very long time.  The curry flavor was so rich and well developed and was an explosion of flavor combined with the fatty marrow.  Also got a dosa and hopper (both of which had great textures) along with a fish and black pork karee - I especially appreciated how all the curries I tried were all very different yet equally delicious.  Also got this sautéed seafood and cut up roti dish that was super unique and special and of course delicious!!!  We got there at 6:20pm, put our names down and went elsewhere to get a drink cause the wait was 1.5+ hrs.  It wasn't too bad though because I could monitor our spot on the website. High recommend this spot!!

YqZ9xPX1IxIC0zS3cipHwQ.text: A girl who loves to eat and eats out most of the time, Hoppers was an amazing experience. I had heard so much about the place and but returned back thrice due to unavailability of a table. This place is always booked! Finally my fourth visit turned out to be brilliant one. Worth the wait!! We ordered almost everything in the menu. The crab curry is a must, must try. The food is spicy here and this is best part about this restaurant. Very friendly staff and they will guide you through the list really well. They do not do desserts, so even better to stuff your belly full with the main course  Advice: They do not take bookings. So if you really want a table, write your name at the door by 6 pm and when your table is ready, they will give you a call. GOOD LUCK!

9XtSmjHUoMZyjcsx9XTycw.text: One star for service. There were three of us looking to have dinner at hoppers on Saturday. Yes, we know the restaurant is very busy and often has a queue. The lady at the door told us it would a THREE hour wait for tables of 3. We said we will put our names down and she was not happy. She was basically hinting we should go away because tables of 3s are not profitable, whereas tables of two or four may be easier to handle than odd numbers. She went to whisper to her coworker, her coworker said just tell them it will be after 10pm. Wait! But don't you close at 10pm!?? They took my phone number and said to follow link to see my place in position. We walked around, then after an hour, we checked the link to see we went from position 27 to position 8!!! We were very excited and surprised the queue went down so quickly. We went back and the same lady said checked her notes and said oh it will have to be after 10pm. I told her it does not take 2 hours to wait 8 position, she said there are still 6 tables of 3s before me. This just to show they are not seating odd number tables and does not respect first come first serve. I would prefer you telling me the truth than to led customers on to wait 3 hours when you don't plan to seat them. Been here before and enjoyed the food. But Just to say bad service, you lost me as your customer.

a_MTi2oVRqsxsRWPKzRPSA.text: The decision has been made and it wasn't a hard one... Hoppers is my favourite restaurant in all of London!!! Maybe I'll change my mind, but seriously, I am so blown away by this place. The first visit here was very lucky. It was kind of rainy and we were seated straight away during a normal dinner time. Normally you have to wait for quite a while. Everything we ordered tasted amazing and I think what makes this place stand out from others is their incredible and very unique flavours. Their crab curry was unbelievable. It came in the shell which was a challenge but the sauce and seasoning was out of this world. We also had the egg hopper. It was totally different than anything I'd had before, and it was perfect for dipping in the curry. The vegetable kothu rothi was massive and had so many flavours and textures. All of the food tastes wonderful on its own, but even better when you eat it together. They also have a number of different sides and chutneys to try which are all very different but add their own special touch. My favourite was the beinjal moju- eggplant/aubergine in a killer seasoning. All in all, the food was filled with spices and flavours that I had never had before and made me wanting to come back and have everything again plus all the other things we didn't try. Their drinks were also good!

AJt5_k90TauThKJo4KQAxQ.text: Definitely a highlight of my trip to London. My partner and I waited for about 45 minutes (checked-in at around 7:30 pm on a Monday evening), and the food was well worth the wait. We ordered the beef varuval/bone marrow to start along with an egg hopper + chicken kari on the side. The flavor of the bone marrow was incredibly rich and deep--definitely recommended! We loved it so much that we had to stop our kind waiters from clearing our dish multiple times (haha we wanted to make sure we got every last drop of the sauce). The egg hopper was also delightful with our kari and bone marrow. You can taste the rice + coconut in the batter, and the fluffy texture as you get closer to the boiled egg center was wonderful. The kari itself was also delicious; tender chicken, earthy and flavorful with a slight heat.The dishes looked to be on the smaller side when they first arrived at our table, but the amount of food ended up being perfect for us. In addition to the food, I appreciated the attentive service and lively atmosphere. The restaurant itself is quite small, but it makes for a cozy and lively space that isn't overwhelmingly loud. Overall a memorable experience that I would love to repeat the next time I visit London!

uRMoziilCl9ily0G5GCUQw.text: I have enjoyed two delicious meals here, lunch and dinner. There is an assortment of dishes and names I am still trying to recall. Luckily there is a glossary on the menu although no photos so trust the Yelp app!I have not had one bad dish, just some that I prefer over others. Their hoppers or thin pancakes are fun and tasty when dipped in curry or your choice of chutney. There are many types to suit your spice level and preference. Our waitress helped to explain the dishes and asked if I preferred relish or sauce so the side dishes were suited to me.It's not a cheap place to eat unless you want a nibble and best to share dishes. The express lunch was nearly £20 which is steep however you do get three small dishes along with a hopper or dosa and tea or coffee. I ended up sharing some of it because it was a lot. Okra curry, lamb koti and the veggie croquet was amazing. The sweet hot tea was also a nice treat.Recommend to come early unless you want to queue up for an hour during the dinner rush. Service is slow for lunch but better for dinner. Overall a fantastic taste of Sri Lanka.

A3nAFA1TxlmAT-ASm8NAEA.text: This was one of the top dining experiences I had while in London... and perhaps ever. I love food... and eat all the time. There are few dishes that haunt me years and months after I've had them. Hoppers is one of them. It's THAT good.Everything about Hoppers is amazing. The food, drinks, service (if you can get a table). It's really a one of a kind place. I constantly think about the incredible curry, roti, dosa, and cocktails I had when I visited. Here's what you need to know:1. The food is so flavorful. Are you tired of spiceless food? Well, Hoppers can cure you of that problem.2. Don't pass up the chance of have one of the gin cocktails. It will be delicious and incredible. Just try them all.3. The portion size is great. My friend and I had so much food leftover.4. The curry... just order it no matter what. It's amazing.5. Getting a table is a struggle. It's hit or miss.If you're looking for a good spot in Soho, I can't recommend Hoppers enough. If you can get a table, don't pass up an opportunity to eat at one of the best restaurants in London.

HY0IlYxfm3UdllmZlkF_yw.text: Probably my new favorite in London. The fluffy airy hoppers or appams we're dreamy and delicious. The prawn curry hot the spot and the sauces are to die for. We also got the goat curry that was spicy and came with a spicier dipping sauce. I thought I could handle spice until I ate that combo. So there, you have been warned. The coffee was a great ending to this meal. The only nit is I wishes they didn't nickle and dime for sauces and sauce refills. Like 1.5 bucks for a tiny sauce... Really?

l90d_uOKr2fdCPFrk6U-Gw.text: Amazing! We came here for lunch and were not disappointed. The restaurant is rather small and I was concerned we'd have trouble getting a table around prime dinner time, so we opted for lunch instead. We ordered half the entire menu, I swear. I've never had a hopper before and we said yes to getting it with an egg, and it was probably one of the best and most favorite dishes I've had in London to date. I have no idea how they do it, but everything about it works - the flavors, the textures, the sheer beauty of an egg fused perfectly into the bottom of the rounded-out hopper. It was definitely not a cheap lunch, so I probably frequent this place, but I left feeling both very full and satisfied. I'd recommend getting a bunch of small plates that you can split with your table so you can try as much as humanly possible. I would literally come back just for the egg/hopper.

P31pUqt-QZSscu_bfPlA1w.text: As a girl who eats a lot and eats out a lot, this was a new experience for me. I love Indian food and was confident I would like this place but wasn't truly sure what exactly Sri Lankan cuisine was like. It was amazing. The flavors were robust but not overpowering. Luckily I went with someone knowledgeable in the showing and could just sit back and enjoy. We ordered chicken Kari (great flavor), hopper (duh), bone marrow (my first experience. An interesting one, liked the sauce more than the marrow), and multiple dosas. It's a hip little place in a hip little area. A definite find in London.

HMftsP09fNcL86ctWyX_EA.text: "Authentic food and friendly service"Date of Visit: 07.03.18Time: 3pmReview: A great place to eat and not having had Sri-Lanken before this was a nice pleasant surprise. The service was good although the table were small and the resturant shuts down for a period of time between lunch and dinner so you do have a limited time for lunch. I look forward to visiting again. I can see the Soho branch now also offers picnic lunch boxes which would be perfect for the summer. So I will look to try this one day. Dress Code: No dress codeBooking Process: In the Soho branch you cannot book so its walk in only, being small this can be a bit hit and miss as it is a busy place and I prefer to book to be honest so I am not as comfortable with this process. Location: 49 Firth Street, Soho, London, W1D 4SGCuisine Type: Sri-LankenParking: Soho, so not really but there is an NCP car park not to far away. Advice you use the well connected London Transport system.Decor & Lighting: Basic decor, nothing special but still clean, tables are a bit small given the size of the dishes so bear this in mind when ordering. Heating and Cooling: It was a sunny day but everything inside was comfortable. Drinks:  Sunshine juice - Cold Press Orange Juice - Ginger - Turmeric - Honey - Given they do not do normal range of soft drinks i found this refreshing and ginger and turmeric was very subtle. I had the following food: Chicken Kari - A large portion with some great flavour in the curry to me it is like a mix between Thai and Indian.Egg Hopper - This is a light crispy pancake with an egg inside, similar to a south indian Dosa but a nice accompaniment. String Hopper - Another large portion and really light and great taste, it went really well with the chicken to be honest as a substitute to rice which can be a little heavy and filling. Mutton Buriani - Another really large portion and another great dish where the lamb was succulent. Plenty for two or more. Really fresh and one of the best I have eaten. Bill / Cost: £80.00 for 2 (with enough food to take away for another night)Conclusion:  A great place to eat some great food. I would not order as much next time but with so many new items I have never tried I went a bit crazy.

dmOzn0z5QxKO9Kj5v69dvw.text: After hearing great reviews of this place decided to check it out on a weekday evening around 07:30 and was told the wait is more than an hour and a half long.  They do not take reservations but when we arrived there we were given a queue number - decided not to wait then and went someplace else. Came back yesterday around 12:30 which I think was prefect timing as was seated immediately. I was sharing the table with few other customers and was seated on one side of the sofa but it did not feel cramped  - had plenty of space to put my stuff on a nearby chair. The decor inside was basic and simple.Met the owner  Karan - asked for his recommendations since was my first time here. Was very helpful - he asked my preferences etc. He explained the dishes in detail too. Decided to go with the egg hopper - it doesn't come with any chutneys or condiments and they have to be ordered separately. Was told the curries go well with it - The server recommended fish curry - I decided or try out the lamb curry. Curry and hopper combination was great - lamb curry had the perfect amount of spice level and was cooked to perfection. ZvMOPrRm93z0jgah-BWDeA.text: Extremely flavorful and tasty dishes.We stopped in on a Friday evening and were told that there was probably no more availability for the night, but we were able to order take out. We ordered the beef short rib biryani, the stir fry roti, and a bone marrow dish. The biryani and the stir fry roti were extremely delicious and very flavorful, and they kept very well on our walk back home. It's among the best Southeast Asian places I've eaten at, and I'd definitely come back for a sit down meal.

G9o9CqKo-JIuyZTJYWNGCQ.text: I want to disclose up front why this is not a 5 star review. That has nothing to do with the food here which in itself is 5 stars. But it is the way they handle their seating. It is a very small restaurant, with a great ambience. However, all seating is cramped and you will find yourself sharing your table with others. Also they don't take reservations, and you will need to go to the restaurant well before you want to eat, just to put your name down. Then you can go for drinks. In our case, it took over 90 minutes to get a table even though we got there at 6p (on a Saturday). They could simply take paid reservations if they are so busy. Why make people wait around in the cold in busy Soho!On to the food. I tried the Chicken Lollipops, the Mutton roll, the Fish Kari, the Egg Hopper and the Podi Dossa along with a side of Idli. All items were very good but the stand out dishes for me were the Mutton Roll and the Fish Kari. I cannot recommend those enough. I looked over at the person next to me and he was having what looked like the Bone Marrow curry. It looks very good and I might return to try that. Overall, a good experience, which would have been great if I didn't have to wait around.
